awd_titl_txt: Ecology Plus (Ecology+):  Broadening Pathways to Ecological Careers through a Collective Impact Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Ecology Plus (Ecology+) is an NSF INCLUDES Launch Pilot project with a goal of increasing the participation of underrepresented minorities in a broad range of career pathways where ecology plays a role. This project recognizes that both innovative scientific research and wider societal participation are needed for effective and equitable solutions to environmental issues that directly impact societal well-being and national security. Both research and policy are enhanced by full participation of all sectors of society. Despite the existence of multiple programs over many years, barriers to the participation of underrepresented minorities in ecology persist. One overarching systemic issue remains critical: that insufficient connections among programs result in breaks along critical transition points in career pathways. Project activities will lay the groundwork by developing a regional approach to alliance-building that can be extended across the nation. 


Ecology+ will use a collective impact framework -- characterized by a common agenda, shared measurement, mutually reinforcing activities, continuous communication, and backbone support -- to optimize career guidance and support for undergraduate students, graduate students and early career technical and professional scientists. Starting in the Washington-Baltimore region, key objectives of the project are to develop infrastructure for effective communications among partners with the capacity to expand nationally; map potential career pathways with associated sets of necessary competencies, opportunities and mentors, and; empower alliance participants to overcome institutional barriers and patterns of unconscious bias. Ecology+ will: a) establish an online mentoring platform; b) offer a career fair with motivational talks and guidance on individual career development plans; c) offer a series of relevant skills workshops; d) arrange research or internship experiences, and; e) facilitate awareness and networking opportunities with employers from agencies, business and nonprofit sectors.  The value of Ecology+ lies in its comprehensive, integrated approach that will bring new partners and their resources into a transformative and systemic response to the key barriers affecting underrepresented minorities in science.

por.por_cntn:
EcologyPlus, an INCLUDES Design and Development pilot, used a collective impact framework to address the often bewildering and meandering morass of directions that careers in ecology and related fields may take.  The project connected diverse college students and early career scientists with professional mentors and a community of peers and exposed them to timely and relevant career opportunities in ecology and related environmental fields.

Over the course of the project, EcologyPlus supported two cohorts of 35 undergraduate and graduate students and early career professionals with 12-18 months of one-to-one mentoring which matched them with professionals in a variety of ecological and environmental fields. 

Despite the impact of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, the project offered 26 skills-building workshops, webinars, fieldtrips, networking events, and cohort building activities with the support of its partners. The project also organized three research activities: two weeklong GIS workshops and a virtual short course with The Wilderness Society.  In addition, EcologyPlus organized two Green Opportunities, Diversity Workshop & Career Fairs hosted by the University of the District of Columbia. In total, project activities reached more than 600 participants. 

Student and early career participants received effective individualized guidance year-round by professional mentors facilitated through a mentoring platform.  As a result of EcologyPlus, these participants reported gains in awareness of available opportunities and career information sources. They also reported an increase in awareness of professional networks and participation in these networks. With project-developed resources and tools, EcologyPlus provided: 1) self-assessments and road maps for participants on possible career paths, 2) opportunities for participants to learn skill sets needed for careers in these fields, and; 3) guidance on how to better apply for jobs at a variety of levels. Participants also noted that EcologyPlus was effective in creating a sense of belonging in ecology and related environmental fields. 

In addition to participant support, EcologyPlus led and contributed to local and national conversations on ways to promote a culture of inclusion and equity.  EcologyPlus facilitated a number of working groups, workshops, and forums among environmental organizations and agencies that focused on employer recruitment,  retention and mentoring. As a broader impact, university partners associated with EcologyPlus formed an active, regionally-focused working group  that has organized inter-university Earth Day activities, fostered cross-campus interactions among students and student groups, and opened sharing opportunities across programs.   

EcologyPlus had a demonstrable and direct impact on lowering some of the most common barriers that exist for minorities and underrepresented groups pursuing careers in the fields of ecology and environmental science.
